steps.title: Intro
steps.description: Let me tell you a little bit about how I work with parents, so you can get a gentle idea about the short time we are about to spend together, ok?

steps.title: This is NOT ...
steps.description:
I know we all had our share of things that did not work, so here's a quick list of what we will NOT be doing …

❌ Therapy (psychoanalysis, gestalt, or any other)  
❌ Life advice / coaching / counseling  
❌ Positive affirmations / Mindfulness  
❌ Diet / Physical Exercise / Medication  
❌ Reiki, spiritual healing, chakras, meditation, energy healing  
❌ Breathing exercises  
❌ Communication with other dimensions or beings  
❌ Empathy and having someone to talk to  
❌ Classic NLP / CBT

answers.text: So how is it going to work?

steps.title: How's this going to work
steps.description:
${echo}

I’m glad you asked, so here’s how this is going to work.

I will ask you some questions, some more trivial than others, and offer you things to try.

Whatever works for you, keep, whatever doesn't, file away in the

"things I've tried and haven't worked for me yet" drawer.

Sounds good?
steps.notes:
I will never impose anything on you. You only answer what you’re comfortable sharing, and only do what you’re comfortable doing.

Everything that we do is reversible, and we are only trying things to understand what works for YOU.

If at any point you feel uncomfortable, or something that we do isn’t to your liking, just message me, I respond personally to every single message I get.

I rely on your feedback to know how to proceed. Are we together on this?

steps.title: Privacy & content free processes
steps.description: Most of what we’ll do together is content free, meaning I do NOT need the details of your experience, so you get total privacy.
steps.notes: i.e. if you have a disturbing image in your mind from 2 years ago, all I need to know is "disturbing image from two years ago". I do not need the content and details of the image itself.

steps.title: Between you and me ...
steps.description: Needless to say (but here I go saying it anyways, just in case ...), **EVERYTHING in our interaction stays between us**. Whatever you write or say to me, stays only with me, unless you explicitly state otherwise.
steps.notes: I don’t share anything with anyone, no matter how close to me that person is, and how much I trust them. Privacy is SACRED. No one will even know we’ve worked together.

answers.text: Privacy IS sacred. I respect that.
I like that, and I'm OK sharing

steps.title: Value first model & pricing
steps.description: You decide how much to pay AFTER you’ve gotten useful results and benefits from our work, and what you learn and experience in our time together. So no need to reach for your wallet quite yet ;)
steps.notes:
Many parents who come to me have been through some grieving processes work that were slow, expensive, not very helpful, and many times even harmful.

This is my only income, and I do $$$ to continue helping & working with parents, but giving you better control over your mind, body, and internal processes is our #1 priority, together with reconnecting you to the good feelings and experiences with your child.

Sounds good? Are we together on this?

answers.text: That's an interesting model, mind expanding on that?

steps.title: Name
steps.description:
Let me personalize this experience for you with 4 quick questions.

What is your name?
steps.notes: Nickname or initials for reference will work as well

steps.title: Child's name
steps.description:
I'm Adam, pleased to e-meet you ${s6}.

And your child's name?
steps.notes: Nickname or initials for reference will work as well

steps.title: Genders
steps.description: Which of the following describes you best?

answers.text: I’m a Mother grieving my son
I’m a Mother grieving my daughter
I’m a Father grieving my son
I’m a Father grieving my daughter

steps.title: Transition
steps.description: How did your child transitioned?
steps.notes: I’m only asking this to know which piece of information to present to you next.

steps.title: Drug abuse
steps.description: Did you find your child / witnessed them overdosing?
steps.notes: Pick the answer that resonates with you the most

answers.text: Yes, it’s still a shock thinking about it
No, but I have reconstructed it in my mind
No, but getting the news was very shocking

steps.title: Drug abuse
steps.description:
${echo}

Parents I’ve worked with had hard time savoring their child’s memory since they replayed the overdose scene over and over again in their head.

The mix of shock (and sometimes anger, blame, resentment, and guilt/regret), often makes it much harder (and sometimes impossible) to remember your child in a pleasant way.

The first process we will do together will soften your response to that event, and reorient you to the last happy memory with your child, so you can focus and attend to the good feelings you have associated with them, and remember them in a way that honors them.
steps.notes:
“I like how you’ve helped me. God’s Blessings to you and your work!

It made me laugh inside, yet it took me to a healthy Anthony, which what he’d want for me.
Yes, I’m not as sad or angry or regretful or anxious. I see him standing tall.

Thank you for this opportunity. Thank you for your work for us that need the healing. Unbelievable, unexpected, yet real now, I see his corpse peaceful. I accept and release that burden so that Anthony will be at peace.

Much love and success for your work! God bless you!”

**Alexandra M. Rush** - Mother of Anthony

![Alexandra's Rush](http://res.cloudinary.com/goldylucks/image/upload/v1/users/alexandra_rush_avatar)

answers.text: OK, let’s give that a try

answers.text: OK, let’s give that a try

steps.title: Other
steps.description:
***${s09}***

Parents I’ve worked with had hard time savoring their child’s memory since they attended to the end of the relationship, in which there are usually unpleasant experiences (getting the news/finding the child, the funeral and all the events regarding it, etc)

The first process we will do together will soften your response to that, and reorient you to the last happy memory with your child, so you can focus and attend to the good feelings you have associated with them, and remember them in a way that honors them.
steps.notes:
"I like this “brain education”, different than therapy. Tears were always in my eyes when I thought of him. mostly the suffering he had to go through.

This made me understand how intensively I was living in this traumatized experience. Like I literary was living it through every day every moment. I don't hold on to heavy, sad memories anymore. Like I don't need to force myself every day to tell me that something terrible happened. I can choose how to feel. it is great :)

And the reverse was fun."

**Vita Steina** - Mother of Ralph, transitioned due to illness, after long period in the hospital

![Vita Steina](http://res.cloudinary.com/goldylucks/image/upload/v1/users/vita_steina_avatar)

answers.text: OK, let’s give that a try

steps.title: Illness
steps.description:
Parents I’ve worked with had hard time savoring their child’s memory since they attended to the end of the relationship, in which the illness and its effects were increasingly more and more unpleasant.

The first process we will do together will soften your response to that, and reorient you to the last happy memory with your child, so you can focus and attend to the good feelings you have associated with them, and remember them in a way that honors them.
steps.notes:
"I like this “brain education”, different than therapy. Tears were always in my eyes when I thought of him. mostly the suffering he had to go through.

This made me understand how intensively I was living in this traumatized experience. Like I literary was living it through every day every moment. I don't hold on to heavy, sad memories anymore. Like I don't need to force myself every day to tell me that something terrible happened. I can choose how to feel. it is great. :)

And the reverse was fun."

**Vita Steina** - Mother of Ralph, died from illness after long period in the hospital

![Vita Steina](http://res.cloudinary.com/goldylucks/image/upload/v1/users/vita_steina_avatar)

answers.text: OK, let’s give that a try

steps.title: Suicide
steps.description: Did you witness it?

answers.text: Yes, it’s still a shock thinking about it
No, but I have reconstructed it in my mind
No, but getting the news was very shocking

steps.title: Suicide
steps.description:
${echo}

Parents I’ve worked with had hard time savoring their child’s memory since they replayed the suicide over and over again in their head.

The mix of shock (and sometimes anger, blame, resentment, and guilt/regret), often makes it much harder (and sometimes impossible) to remember your child in a pleasant way.

The first process we will do together will soften your response to that event, and reorient you to the last happy memory with your child, so you can focus and attend to the good feelings you have associated with them, and remember them in a way that honors them.
steps.notes:
"When I think of him now, I am being directed to Tyler happy and smiling. I do tend to focus more on seeing Tyler before the incident when he was happy.

It feels Warm and comfy, my mind is rewinding to the happy times with T. I am happy with that."

**Elizabeth West**, mother of Tyler, transitioned by suicide

![Elizabeth West](http://res.cloudinary.com/goldylucks/image/upload/v1/users/elizabeth_west_avatar)

answers.text: OK, let’s give that a try

answers.text: Yes, it’s still a shock thinking about it
No, but I have reconstructed it in my mind

steps.title: Accident
steps.description:
${echo}

Parents I’ve worked with had hard time savoring their child’s memory since they replayed the accident over and over again in their head.

The feelings of shock (and sometimes anger, blame, resentment, and guilt/regret), often makes it much harder (and sometimes impossible) to remember your child in a pleasant way.

The first process we will do together will soften your response to the accident, and reorient you to the last happy memory with your child, so you can focus and attend to the good feelings you have associated with them, and remember them in a way that honors them.
steps.notes:
"Pretty interesting ... to see things in reverse ... and the circus music was perfect.  It reduced the personal injury I felt to just a set of decisions that were made - no judgments...nothing personal…

this is quite brilliant… Your open ended questions are thoughtful and insightful...

I feel a softness towards his presence....your process magnified his presence and minimized the absence and reduced the trauma details of his exit....a lot more than I thought was possible. And I have traveled far on this process...trust me....

You made a perfect ending to my day.  Thank you so much."

**Beth D'Angelo** - Mother of Sean, transitioned due to a car accident

![Beth Deangelo](http://res.cloudinary.com/goldylucks/image/upload/v1/users/beth_deangelo_avatar2)

answers.text: OK, let’s give that a try

steps.title: Peaceful ending
steps.description:
OK, on the next page I will redirect you to the next process we’ll do, called “Peaceful Ending”, which most parents find tremendously helpful and healing.

It will help you attend to the good feelings you have towards ${s7}, and soften the response to the end of the relationship.

answers.text: I would love to experience more peace
